message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of vesicular lesions on both elbows and knees suggests dermatitis herpetiformis, which is a manifestation of celiac disease, a type of malabsorption. Transmural inflammation of the colon is associated with Crohn’s disease. Erythema nodosum and acanthosis nigricans are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pruritic skin lesions on the elbows and knees are most likely to be associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) and malabsorption. Options B, C, and D are not associated with skin lesions on the elbows and knees.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has pruritic skin lesions on his elbows and knees, which are clustered vesicular lesions. This is a classic presentation of dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy and malabsorption. None of the other options are associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clustered vesicular lesions on the elbows and knees suggest dermatitis herpetiformis, which is often associated with celiac disease and malabsorption. None of the other options are associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vesicular lesions on the elbows and knees suggest dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with malabsorption. The other options are not associated with skin lesions in these locations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clustered vesicular lesions on the elbows and knees suggest dermatitis herpetiformis, which is commonly associated with malabsorption, especially gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease). Transmural inflammation of the colon is associated with inflammatory bowel disease and erythema nodosum is a skin manifestation of several conditions including infections, sarcoidosis, and inflammatory bowel disease. Acanthosis nigricans is not associated with clustered vesicular lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s pruritic skin lesions on his elbows and knees suggest a case of dermatitis herpetiformis, which is often associated with celiac disease and malabsorption. None of the other options are associated with clustered vesicular lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pruritic skin lesions, clustered vesicular lesions on elbows and knees, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis, which is an autoimmune disorder associated with celiac disease, a form of malabsorption. All other options are associated with different conditions or symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of pruritic skin lesions on the elbows and knees suggests a skin condition such as dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with malabsorption. Transmural inflammation of the colon is associated with Crohn’s disease, which presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. Erythema nodosum presents with tender nodules on the lower extremities, and acanthosis nigricans presents with thickened, velvety patches of skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clustered vesicular lesions on the elbows and knees are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy or celiac disease, causing malabsorption. Transmural inflammation of the colon is associated with inflammatory bowel disease, not with dermatitis herpetiformis. Erythema nodosum and acanthosis nigricans are not associated with clustered vesicular lesions on the elbows and knees.
